Rather than being controlling, my parents are always overly worried about me because I'm the only child.  During pri sch, mom checked my bag everyday, see if there's anything out of the ordinary, checked my wallet and ask me what I had spent on. I had to try and recall everything.  I had to tell her my whereabouts after school (this happened until Poly or even after I began working). After every few hours, she'd text me or call me and ask where I am. (Also, she knew who my friends were, had their numbers and all. And the no dating thing is the same with me).  During compulsory sch camps, they had no choice but to let me go, but told me that I had to call them every night. I didn't because I couldn't. My mom even said she couldn't sleep a wink when I didn't call.  I have never been overseas until now. Not even across the borders (in my mid 20s. Yes, embarrassing. People laugh at me for that.) I can now, but I'm just lazy.  During sec sch, even the compulsory overseas trip, my teacher had to call my dad to convince him. But in the end, she was convinced by him instead... And I'll remember what my dad said when I brought up the trip excitedly forever, "Don't even think about it." My mom only said, "It can't be helped." But I know that she was secretly happy about it.  They wouldn't let me do anything by myself. Not housework, not cooking. But later in my teens, they liked complaining how pampered I am.  Whenever I did something wrong, like not reporting my whereabouts often enough, or just anything that they didn't like, my mom would give me the silent treatment for weeks. That severely lowered my self-esteem. I felt left out, worthless, and unwanted as a child. I have 0 self-esteem. I wanted to take my own life as a child (now I just laugh at how childish it is).  There are more. Basically, they are overly worried about me. But are slowly learning to let things go. This was how I did it.  I told them how if I had to tell them about my whereabouts every time, I'd rather stay home. If they aren't letting me do any work on my own, I'd rather try nothing at all. If they aren't letting me go overseas, fine. I'll be a country bumpkin for the rest of my life. That was how rebellious I am. I get laughed at, but most people are going to criticize their parenting style. I spelled it out to them clearly. If they keep worrying, then I'd rather DO NOTHING and stay in their sight, be a bum until I annoy them (of course it didn't happen). I told them everything calmly. And I said I hated silent treatment because of how manipulative and abusive it is. My mom gave me the silent treatment less frequently as a result, and they started letting things go slowly. I started to be able to breathe then.  But now, getting into a [r/s](https://www.reddit.com/r/s/) is sure a whole new challenge. I was given the silent treatment 4 times in a row within 2 months just because I got a little too intimate with my partner (nothing more than hugging), and I went to another room to talk to my partner over the phone (so she doesn't hear me speak loveydovey). She began mentioning how I'd pick my new partner over her and how I'd throw her away in a heartbeat (which is stupid).  The list goes on. She told me not to go to weddings (I was invited), because they'd make me drunk(?) She said I can't go to my partner's place/can't be alone with him in a private space. Lately, she gave me another silent treatment for hugging my partner. I know, ridiculous. She also began suspecting if I actually gave away my virginity (not true). Ridiculous, yes. So I told her, I don't think I did anything wrong. I can end my [r/s](https://www.reddit.com/r/s/) right now if she thinks it's appropriate. I won't bother finding another for the rest of my life if she just wants me all to herself. I ended it calmly with, if she can't trust me at all, I'll just follow her wherever she goes. And by everywhere, I really mean it. A bird stuck in a cage dies after the owner loses his/her life.  This is still an ongoing thing. It's another obstacle to go through. I'm not encouraging you to be rebellious like me. But talk it out, let your parents know what they are doing to you and how others would think when they see this. I think parents are always learning to be parents, and this can be taught by their children. I guess you can try to talk it out and 'compromise' with your parents. Tell them about how you've been giving in, and how they should be giving in to some things too, since you aren't overly rebellious to be committing crimes like murdering someone or doing drugs or joining a gang. How other kids are living their lives well or even better, even without parents who keep them in a cage. You just want to live your life like how they did themselves. (Also, earning your own money would be a good idea to have them let you go a little). Be calm and don't scream or shout. Raise your voice a little, just to show how firm you are, but not intimidating.  (I also tried to make them report their whereabouts every few hours to me because I can get 'worried' too and they got sick of it.)  Of course, I know some parents aren't negotiable. At least you tried. That's the time where you can start planning and find a way to be independent. Being financially independent is important here.  but all in all, I'm still stuck in my cage, it just expanded after every negotiation... :') Sorry for the long post. You resonate so much with me that it feels like we could even be friends. Hope this helps! Feel free to contact me if you think I could be of help!

Some basic requirements are [listed in their website](https://www.scdf.gov.sg/home/join-us/uniformed-positions) in case you need to have a bookmark.  To answer your questions:  1. You will need to remove it as a measure of confidence. Most paramedics wear [short sleeved vests](https://nyp.jobscentral.com.sg/magazine/polytechnic-2017/img/scdf-masthead.jpg) so your tattoo will be visible.  2. Shift cycles go by this: 2 13-hour daytime shifts, 1 day of "reserved duty" (administrative work), 1 day off, 2 11-hour night shifts, another day of "reserved duty", and 1 day off. By mandate, any work that requires a total of 24 hours of employed work needs to be offset by 48 hours of rest, but because paramedics in SCDF work in staggered 24-hour shifts, there's some flexibility involved.  3. Could you elaborate on what specifics you want to pursue? Urban search and rescue? Mass casualty response? Emergency psychology? These fields are available once you have informed your officer-in-charge of your desired expertise. Usually after you have stabilised for a period of tiem, you can approach your officer-in-charge to plan your career.  4. This will be long, and my memory was taken from my discussions with fellow paramedics that I talked to in my time as a medic, so your mileage may vary.  To start, you will be attached to SAF Medical School seconded under the SCDF organization to train you up on emergency field paramedicine. The total time will be three years, with each year you're being tested on practical and theory work. You will be attached at least six months to a fire station (not sure if by choice or by allocation of manpower resources) to pick up the training on handling real-life patients. You will be mostly performing more advanced duties like needle injection and infusion (IV), airway tubing, vacuum suctioning, ECG and pre-hospital ACLS routines, advanced spine management, extreme traumatic injuries, inter- and post-natal emergencies, and first aid that an NSF medic isn't expected to handle. You will also be learning on field management (e.g. radio reporting, situational awareness etc.) to complement your paramedicine duties. Afterwards, you will be tested, and you need to pass 80% of your assessments to advance to the next level of paramedicine. Only after the completion of 3 years of training will you be officially a paramedic.  Afterwards, you are attached to a fire station, still, not sure if by choice or by current allocation. You have two overall in charge: the commanding officer for the fire station, and the paramedic officer-in-charge of EMS. You will follow the regulations as set by the fire station CO, (as an overall leader in charge of the fire station representing SCDF at large), and you will follow the occupation regulations as set forth by the OIC (operational procedures, case paperwork, medical logistics etc.). Depending on your level of experience, you can be seconded as an assistant to the OIC, or you can be posted as a fast-response paramedic (usually it's performed by paramedics converted from fire and rescue units).  Most firefighters are OK with paramedics, but because the operational framework is different (one deals with fires and rescue operations, the other, fixing the human body so that it survives the hsopital trip) the only other time you get together is in drills and exercises, as well as station bonding activities and various inter-department and inter-division activities. If firefighters are physically shiong, you, as a paramedic, it's a mental shiong.  Rewards may/may not include: letter of commendation by members of the public, appearing in newspapers, service awards. Not so nice things include: public complaints, which may affect your performance bonus.  Last but not least, at the very least, you are serving for a noble cause. May you live long and prosper, and may the odds be ever in your favour. Good luck.

We haven't had an updated version for some time after the latest GES was released. Now this is one of the kinds of analysis that when interpreting the visualisation you must have in mind a few caveats. Although it is generally advised not to pick a course solely on remuneration, undoubtedly some are willing to sacrifice their happiness working in a field they later find they dislike for a higher pay, and this is their decision.   That being said, this plot is still interesting enough although with a few important things to note:  \- 10% IGP is not the minimum and may be a good measure, but A lvl Rank points does not solely determine the difficulty of entrance for some courses. Especially for courses with interviews, it is quite often the case where the real difficulty lies in passing the interview and not the RP filtering stage  \- For 85 RP courses, it is obvious that quite a few could, and will be greater than 85 RP. This is just a result of the published IGPs holding GP to be a 'C' grade, a decision made by the universities/MOE.  \- This does not take into account non-normal admission like discretionary admission scheme  \- <Honour> variants of the majors were assumed to have the same IGP. If this does not seem to make sense do point out!  \- Horizontal and Vertical lines are the major-wise mean of the courses analysed here. If your major is not here, it must have meant I could not obtain the data for either dimension.  \- One last thing to add is that starting salary is not necessarily the best measure for some majors. For one example, accountancy is known to have lower starting pay but more well-known for its increment/progression. So do take note of this.  \- Business Analytics is from Computing but it is a Bachelor of Science  \- the usual problems for GES in general still apply, like reporting bias, sample size etc. (although all here are >30, but that's still not significantly big).  \- Decided to do for gross starting remuneration but basic could also hold some insights.  \- For obvious reasons, there is a 3/4 year lag between the latest batch(IGP) and the batch whose GES was considered.  ​  Data was taken from MOE at: [https://www.moe.gov.sg/docs/default-source/document/education/post-secondary/files/web-publication-nus-ges-2019.pdf](https://www.moe.gov.sg/docs/default-source/document/education/post-secondary/files/web-publication-nus-ges-2019.pdf)  Some footnotes copy and pasted from their report:  "  6. Data on law, medicine and pharmacy graduates is obtained from a follow-up survey on 2018 graduates after they have completed their  one-year practical law course/pupillage/housemanship/first-year residency/practical training. Data on architecture graduates is  obtained from a follow-up survey on 2016 architecture graduates after they have completed their practical training.  7. The Bachelor of Environmental Studies degree is a multidisciplinary programme that allows students to specialise in either  Environmental Biology within the Faculty of Science or Environmental Geography within the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences.  8. \*: Data is based on a sample size of fewer than 30 respondents. "  ​  For more caveats, take a look at their the link above, their report is quite comprehensive for most intents and purposes.  With the 4-partition, linear model line may not be needed but I have left it there in case some are interested to see.  ​  Last advice is that cliche as it seems, remember to consider if you value your happiness more than such financial considerations. A major, though not always, could go a long way in determining a large part of your life.

Read the immediate parent thread above - this discussion pertains to what the USA and its leaders have been doing.  If you don't like that, make your comments in another thread.  Since you would rather read the Jakarta Post (lol - the same Jakarta Post that accused Singapore of not sharing information on cases) than the WHO reports I referred you to, here is a link to spoonfeed you: https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/who-china-joint-mission-on-covid-19-final-report.pdf  It takes time and diplomacy to assemble and approve an official WHO team to visit an outbreak epicenter for an official report (such as the one I linked).  Members of the epidemic-specific investigative team from WHO were carefully selected and vetted, based on their individual experience, countries of expertise, and type of skills they would bring to the team. After the selection process, they then had to be additionally vetted and approved by their home countries as well as China, and cleared to visit high-risk areas (i.e. places where the virus was rampant) that were technically already on strict governmental lockdown.  Note also that the WHO already had regular WHO staff in China (i.e. in the WHO China branches, in main Chinese cities) from the beginning.  There was never any point in time in which there was zero WHO presence in China during this outbreak.    The international team that carried out the Feb 16-24 investigation was comprised of experts from all over the world (including a Singapore  expert).  Taiwan has had access to WHO data one way or another, even though it is not "formally acknowledged" as a country.  This is how things work diplomatically and internationally - just because a country is not a WHO member does not mean it will not receive the data through unofficial, unacknowledged means.  Note also that travel bans are a two-way process in that if one country is on lockdown, the flow of travelers is automatically reduced regardless of whether the other country implements bans.  For example, Malaysia is now on lockdown - and so a Singapore travel ban against Malaysia would not currently make a sizeable difference to the influx of Malaysians to Singapore.  That said, China has banned solo travel to Taiwan since mid-2019 (you can easily check this through multiple news sources).  In effect, any bans coming from Taiwan in 2020 have had a negligible influence on pre-existing travel flow.  >*"virus can come from anywhere, even SG has wet markets. as to their TCM wildlife trade, it has to stop and i think they're really gonna clamp down hard this time, or else we'll get another round. We should be sharing data with TW/HK/SK those who successfully play defence, as well as look at the italian data and make sure we have mitigation steps if it gets to that stage."*  I have no idea why you went off on an unrelated tangent regarding TCM wildlife trade and sharing data, as these points are unrelated to the original discussion.  Data-sharing between countries is a given, and has taken place since January - every country has sent data through international channels (the WHO has a formal process for collating data from all countries and making sure it is shared).  Singapore has followed all WHO-recommended international procedures for data-sharing, and was even commended by the WHO as a country that has been quick and prompt to fill and submit the WHO forms/reports to facilitate this sharing. In a pandemic, data-sharing is centralized by the WHO, and is not on the informal level (i.e. not subject to country-to-country agreements) you imply it is.  I strongly suggest reading up on international crisis response procedures and protocols, especially WHO-affiliated reports and those authored by experts with a background in public health and epidemiology.  Pandemic management involves both public health expertise as well as diplomacy management - there are standard ways in which this plays out during an epidemic/pandemic.  If you are really interested in learning more about pandemic crisis management, I suggest you look to (for starters) WHO publications as well as peer-reviewed publications in well-established academic journals.

> And so I believe there is no longer any need to debate this point.  My original comment is not a truth claim about heaven, but one about life on Earth - sorrow and sadness and depth lends depth to our current existence, and these things would not be present in Heaven (I think you won't disagree here since you define Heave as without sorrow, heaven, or death).   > Firstly, I did not state that "God works in ways we cannot comprehend". I have always held that God is his actions are always explained through analyzing scripture. Sometimes this is given explicitly (in the case of Job)… Therefore it is more accurate to say "God always reveals the reasons behind his actions, even if it may not be initially understood".  Actually I don't think this is an accurate summary of your earlier position. You have previously stated that "*I am merely pointing out how a being of infinite intelligence might do something that we are incapable of understanding, but we are provided with sufficient scriptural evidence that God has our best interests at heart.*", which I took to understand that God may do things that we have no means of understanding, however the Bible says that he has our interests at heart. Clearly, having our interests at heart, and understanding God's actions are different issues, since we can believe that he has out interests at heart without fully understanding what he is doing.   > Nope, that does not add up logically in the story of Genesis. Why would God create the tree of the knowledge of good and evil then? If he explained to A&E what is good and evil then there was no need to create the tree. It is completely unreasonable.  No, I'm not saying that he needs to fully explain to them good and evil, because then they would not even need the tree. I am expanding though on your reasoning that we can fill in reasonable gaps in the bible. So if God says "do not do X or Y will happen", if he has to give some explanation on what Y is, "death is what happens when you stop living and you will come back to heaven" (you can see the logical problems of explaining death in a pre-fall world where no one has died, and so the system of good souls going to heaven has not even been established), then he logically would give some explanation on what X is as well "do not eat the fruit of the tree because it contains knowledge that is forbidden to you that only I as God can know and you cannot know".   > So, what is your stance on this matter? If you had the power to decide, would you: A) take the life of a child and bring it into heavenly paradise where there is no suffering OR B) allow the child to live, brought up in a violent environment, surrounded by evil people with evil corrupted hearts, likely to be raped and tortured (these are not unfounded scenarios. We have seen the actions of the Sodomites, whom God deemed too evil and needed to be destoryed. When they found out there were visitors in the city, they set out to rape them. Genesis 19:1-4)  Well this is a false dichotomy for an omnipotent being right? If I had God's power to decide, my options surely are not A or B. Plus I want to clarify here - if the children (referring to new born) are so corrupt that they cannot be redeemed and have to be killed, how do they go to heaven? I know the traditional view that all children are innocent and hence to go to heaven by default, but then you are also saying that these children are inherently tainted.   > And since both are equally probable, I know you will pick "nature" as the explanation and say innocent babies who could not have adotped evil practices were killed, but I think at this point in time it is fair to say that science that applies to us as human beings, past, present, and future, holds true in that "corrupted" genes can indeed be passed down. While you will say this is adding to the scripture, I'd argue that it is fair to add in something that has been scientifically proven to be an innate trait of human beings that affects us now just as it affected us then.  Yes but the science you are citing does not say that "nature"/genes are the exclusive manner in which psychopathy is passed down. Both nature and nurture are influences. And the science is just on psychopathy and not "evil practices" generally.  If we accept that nurture plays an equal part and/or is equally probable, then the basis for killing babies is no longer strong, since you can obviously remove the baby from the evil environment and it will have a chance to grow up normally. So I think that your position is still problematic, since you are specifically relying on this "nature" argument to kill newborn babies.   > Logic comes from God, so it would make sense that He would not be subject to something that came from Him.  Then I don't follow why you think God cannot do illogical things. If logic comes from him, then what he does will automatically become logical. On this particular point I logically actually don't see the problem in just saying that God can square a circle. I would even apply your own arguments about us not being able to fully understand how God works. Just as an ant does not fully grasp the concept of three dimensions, God could exist in dimensions beyond our three and so he would be entirely able to square a circle, just like how we can cube a square.   > I'm not sure what you are trying to prove here.  The point I'm making is actually just in "Adam has become like one of us". Because if God is a source of knowledge, then saying that Adam has become like God, suggests that Adam is now a source of knowledge. If the point was simply that Adam possesses knowledge, then God would have just said "Adam now has knowledge of Good and Evil", rather than making the specific comparison to himself.   > In the case of using the Isrealites to exact divine judgement via war, a flood would kill the Isrealites as well.  Well then clearly he can save the Israelite tribes just as he saved Noah's family.   > Another reason is to demonstrate that God always keeps His promises. He promised to never flood the Earth again. Genesis 9:11.  His specific promise was "I establish my covenant with you: Never again will all life be destroyed by the waters of a flood; never again will there be a flood to destroy the earth.”. Again as an omnipotent being there are plenty of other ways of wiping out life on earth - volcanoes, covid viruses, and so on. The flood is merely just one way that he has promised not to use again.   So this brings us back to the question of why, despite there being many other options that does not require God to rely or use the evil of men to carry out his judgment, he chose to declare war.

A little-known enclave of black-and-white heritage homes near the  base of Mount Faber that are typically occupied by expatriates and  well-heeled Singaporeans could soon be opened up for a heritage trail.  This follows a recent $1 million refurbishment of five bungalows there, funded by the Singapore Land Authority (SLA).  Constructed between 1908 and 1919, the Pender Road homes were part of  the first wave of colonial black-and-white bungalows to be built in  Singapore.  Heritage experts, including blogger Jerome Lim, are excited that the  gated complex is being opened up to Singaporeans. Mr Lim said such tours  help give Singaporeans a better grasp of the various heritage  structures dotting the island.  In this case, tours will provide a better understanding of the evolution of the landed colonial-era homes here, he said.  SLA - which manages around 1,700 residential state properties across  Singapore, of which 500 are colonial black-and-white bungalows - has  organised heritage tours for other state properties under its watch,  including the[ former Pasir Panjang Power Station](https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/pasir-panjang-power-district-up-for-development-next-year-ideas-from-public-on-exhibition) and Changi Hospital.  Last month, it gave The Straits Times an exclusive look at the  refreshed Pender Road spaces which can be rented out for two-or  three-year periods at prevailing market rates.  The  houses' damaged and leaking roofs have been retiled and waterproofed,  while the lightning protection systems, electrical wiring and the site's  sewage infrastructure have all been upgraded. The bungalows' original  timber floors were also repaired and varnished.  These bungalows, which lie in the Southern Ridges conservation area,  were identified by SLA for maintenance and repair works late last year.  An SLA spokesman said such works are usually scheduled upon expiry of  existing tenancies, following building management inspections.  According to Knight Frank, the site's managing agent, the houses at  1, 2, 3, 4A and 5 Pender Road have a land area of between 1,100 sq m and  4,400 sq m. Rental rates start at $10,000.  Mr Lim highlighted the bungalows' rarity and heritage value. He said  Pender Road's black-and-white bungalows differ from others around the  island, many of which technically should not be described as black and  white.     For instance, timber is used more extensively across the Pender Road  clutch, unlike in the majority of colonial bungalows in Singapore,  including those in places like Sembawang, Alexandra Park, Malcolm Road  and Temenggong Road. Designed by the Public Works Department, the bulk  of these other bungalows were mainly constructed with concrete and  largely built after 1925.  The Pender Road bungalows were built for the Eastern Extension  Telegraph Company by architectural firm Swan & Maclaren. Among its  staff were cable jointers and engineers who lived there until the 1950s.  Its cable depot, workshops and wharves were at Bukit Chermin - close to  Pender Road.  📷   Related Story   #### [Belle of Pender Road](https://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/home-design/belle-of-pender-road)  Mr Lim said: "Companies then took really good care of these workers,  who were considered rather fortunate. It was an era where they hired  architects to build homes for their skilled staff.  "The company would even attach servants to take care of them and the  spaces they occupied. Servant entrances were built at the back of these  bungalows."  Another highlight in Pender Road is house No. 4. Its L-shaped design  made it possible for single rooms to be carved out along its long  corridors for the bachelor staff of the Eastern Extension Telegraph  Company.  These staff members were generally from the cable jointing  department. They would have come together after work in the evenings in  the common sitting area of their home with the wooden shutter windows  flung open, noted Mr Lim.    Related Story   #### [Memories of 17A Keong Saik Road go from book to dramatised reading at #BuySingLit festival](https://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/arts/memories-of-17a-keong-saik-road-go-from-book-to-dramatised-reading-at-buysinglit)    Related Story   #### [The Life List: 7 old-school eateries with over 80 years of history ](https://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/food/the-life-list-as-old-or-older-than-tan-hock-seng-cake-shop-7-eateries-over-80-years)  He added: "I think it's important to maintain the buildings. The idea  is for people to want to live in them and rent them. Buildings that are  lived in tend to survive better than those that aren't."  The SLA spokesman added that maintenance and repair works to restore  and upgrade its properties are ongoing and take into consideration the  age of the structures.

1) for the sake of simplicity, I'm just going to refer to both "pre-fall life" and "heaven" as the same thing. Having no point of reference does not eliminate the possibility of then Heaven having greater depth than life on Earth. I should clarify and rephrase: there is no sufficient scriptural text to give us a clear picture of what Heaven is like. We are given glimpses of it though.  Here are some scriptures of Heaven:  >Rev 21:4 He will wipe away every tear from their eyes, and death shall be no more, neither shall there be mourning, nor crying, nor pain anymore, for the former things have passed away.”  There is no death, no negative emotions in Heaven.  >John 14:2 In my Father's house are many rooms. If it were not so, would I have told you that I go to prepare a place for you?  There is a house, though it could be metaphorical. Since Jesus also spoke of "the Kingdom of Heaven" the imagery that conjures is that of a city with many houses and buildings.  >1 Cor 2:9 But, as it is written, “What no eye has seen, nor ear heard, nor the heart of man imagined, what God has prepared for those who love him”—  As I have mentioned, Heaven is a place no one can even conceive of what it is like for no one has even seen, heard or even imagined what it is like. Whatever we are capable of imagining Heaven is like, it is better than that.  There are other scriptures on Heaven but I think these are sufficient for the sake of this discussion and my stance that Heaven is a place that is like a city. It is a kingdom. For that reason I believe it holds more depth than life on Earth. Perhaps there will be jobs and activities for everyone, but whatever it is, we are literally incapable of imagining it. What would it be like to have a new sense? To see a new color?   2) Apart from naming animals they were also tasked with ruling over all the animals. He also told them to be fruitful and multiply. Surely God gave them sufficient thinking skills to accomplish the tasks of ruling over animals and raising children. One would require some form of critical thinking skills to know not to toss an animal that is unable to swim into the water, or throw a fish onto land.   3)  >Judgment can well involve merciless killing.  Yes but that wouldn't be objectively moral judgement. That's not how God has acted. God has always punished those deserving of punishment.  On your example of the flood killing innocent animals, it must be noted that animals do not have souls like humans do. That being said, we must be careful not to impose what we believe to be moral onto the actions of God, who is objectively moral and has authority over all creation. I am inclined to believe that this is merely a transition for the animals from earth into paradise. For the evil people who were rightfully sentenced in the flood, their destination would be very different.   Deuteronomy 24:16 is a precept laid down by which the legal system of Israel would function once they were established in the land. It was not the right of the human courts to exact capital punishment from the children of guilty parents if the children were not personally guilty of the crime. It only applies specifically to the Isrealites at that specific point in time. That which restricts the power of human courts does not restrict the right or authority of God.  Furthermore, psychopathy is a genetic trait that can be passed down through generations that corrupts moral reasoning.   From this article:   https://edition.cnn.com/2015/06/16/health/birth-of-psychopath/index.html  >Psychopathy is also an inherited condition, according to J. Reid Meloy, forensic psychologist and author of "The Psychopathic Mind." "The more severe the psychopathy, the greater the inheritance for the disorder," he said.  Therefore, generations of psychopaths will lead to the increased birthrates of psychopaths, and over thousands of years, every newborn would indeed have psychopathy.   4) since this is similar to the above point, im going to leave it out as it is redundant.

>The true position is simply that we do not know the scope of heaven and so we do not know whether it lacks depth in comparison to life on Earth.   While I do not agree entirely with you, since you have made a truth claim to this, I'm sure you would be satisfied with your own reply to your initial statement:  >1. Death, sadness, and misery are part of the human experience and it has given our lives depth which would be absent if we continued to live in a Utopian garden paradise. We would not be able to appreciate things like a Greek tragedy, the loss of a friend, disappointment and fear that we overcome, without living in a world with brief lives and sadness.  And so I believe there is no longer any need to debate this point.   >I don't think it is fair to say I have shifted goal posts, because I specifically included a moral decision in the very first time you asked me to define critical thinking - "Critical thinking has a fairly broad definition, but I consider at its heart would be the ability to evaluate two competing positions both with benefits and flaws, and arriving at a judgment call. Like I said, it would involve being able to answer a question like the one I posed earlier about letting innocent people got to jail. Without knowledge of good and evil do you think Adam can answer such a question?"  Well then it's fair to say we don't agree on the definition of "critical thinking". I have stated my definition, and I make it a clear distinction from "moral reasoning". It would appear that you would consider "moral reasoning" as a quintessential aspect of "critial thinking" but I do not. So to answer your 2nd initial point:  >2. I am not sure how it is logically possible to have critical thinking without an understanding of what is good and evil. Critical thinking by definition involves the evaluation of whether something is good or bad. If pre-tree of knowledge humans simply lived in a state of "Listen to God" then that is not critical thinking, it would be total subservience to a higher power (which can be a good or bad thing, depending on your perspective).  By my definition of what critical thinking is, a state of "Listen to God" does not involve total subservience, and actually the very act of A&E's choice to disobey disproves your very claim that they are in total subservience. The story tells us that they disobeyed, which means they were not totally subservience. In any case… I'd argue that "the evaluation of wheather something is good or bad" is actually the definition of "moral reasoning" and not "critical thinking"… but you're free to have your own worldview. I think that reasonably clears up this point as well.  >But by the same view that you state else where that God is infinitely intelligent and works in ways that we cannot comprehend, why should God be required to adhere to what we think is "logical sense" in setting rules for Adam? If we allow this kind of reasonable inference, then it is also reasonable to expect that God would have given some explanation to Adam on what exactly is "knowledge of good and evil".   Firstly, I did not state that "God works in ways we cannot comprehend". I have always held that God is his actions are *always* explained through analyzing scripture. Sometimes this is given explicitly (in the case of Job)… Therefore it is more accurate to say "God always reveals the reasons behind his actions, even if it may not be initially understood". In this way, we are able to have good faith that God will act in the same ways he has acted before as per recorded in the scripture and these reasons *always* make logical sense and demonstrate rightful judgement.  That being said, to answer your question:  >why should God be required to adhere to what we think is "logical sense" in setting rules for Adam?   Because it is logically consistent and scripturally evidential for God to act in a logically coherent manner.  >If we allow this kind of reasonable inference, then it is also reasonable to expect that God would have given some explanation to Adam on what exactly is "knowledge of good and evil".   Nope, that does not add up logically in the story of Genesis. Why would God create the tree of the knowledge of good and evil then? If he explained to A&E what is good and evil then there was no need to create the tree. It is completely unreasonable.  Saying "if you do A then B" without explaining what is "B" is completely unreasonable as well. It should follow, and be logically coherent that B, was explained to A&E. It should also follow, and be logically coherent, that the existence of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, (supported by scripture that revealed that A&E did indeed gain knowledge that they previously did not have prior to eating the fruit), it is reasonable to conclude that God did not explain to them what "knowledge of good and evil" is. They acquired that knowledge through eating the fruit.  >Sure it would not be good for a child to be born into this place, but that is a separate issue from whether it is just to kill a newborn child that has been born into such a place. This is where I see you adding reason to the bible.  So, what is your stance on this matter? If you had the power to decide, would you:  A) take the life of a child and bring it into heavenly paradise where there is no suffering  Or  B) allow the child to live, brought up in a violent environment, surrounded by evil people with evil corrupted hearts, likely to be raped and tortured (these are not unfounded scenarios. We have seen the actions of the Sodomites, whom God deemed too evil and needed to be destoryed. When they found out there were visitors in the city, they set out to rape them. Genesis 19:1-4)  >The logical inference fails because the notion of "pass down the bloodline" (or genetic transfer of evil) has to compete with an obvious competing and equally likely (if not more) reason that people who are raised in an evil society are more likely to be evil. Nature versus Nurture, if you will. Both explanations are equally likely to explain why Lot's daughters (who grew up in Sodom), or surviving Canaanites tended towards evil, and continued to spread evil practices.   >If there are two competing, equally probably explanations, then we cannot simply just pick one under the guise of calling it a logical inference.   While this is true, as the stories illustrste, it doesn't matter which is passed down, "nature" in the form of genetics or "nurture" in the form of learned evil practices. What is true is that evil was passed down from the survivors. And since both are equally probable, I know you will pick "nurture" as the explanation and say innocent babies who could not have adotped evil practices were killed, but I think at this point in time it is fair to say that science that applies to us as human beings, past, present, and future, holds true in that "corrupted" genes can indeed be passed down. While you will say this is adding to the scripture, I'd argue that it is fair to add in something that has been scientifically proven to be an innate trait of human beings that affects us now just as it affected us then. As such I will keep my stance that what is passed down is "nature", or corrupted genes.  >Then wouldn't this mean that God is subject to the requirements of logic?   Logic comes from God, so it would make sense that He would not be subject to something that came from Him. Rather, logic is subject to God. What I know is that God has never demonstrated to perform any illogical acts. From the three aspects of God I have listed, and supported by scripture detailing all acts of God to be logical, I can reasonably conclude that God will always act in a logical manner.   >Again, this appears to me that at very least God is limited by the requirements of logic.   Just because God chooses to be logical doesn't mean he is subject to the requirements of logic. Just because I choose to keep my eyes closed doesn't mean I am blind.  >I'm making a point based on the wording of Gensis. Even if we adopt your formulation that God is the source of knowledge, it would not make logical sense (since it seems it is necessary for God to act logically) for God to say that Adam has become like one of us, with knowledge of good and evil. Does the "like one of us" denote that Adam too has become a source of knowledge?   I'm not sure what you are trying to prove here. How does, and I quote you, "Adam has become like one of us, with knowledge of good and evil." become "Adam has become like one of us, the source of the knowledge of good and evil." Or even, going back to your previous statement "Adam has become like one of us, knowledge".  You are changing the meaning of the sentences and I'm not sure what you are even trying to point out.  Perhaps you are trying to make a distinction between "God is the source of knowledge" and "God possesses knowledge". If that is your point then my reply would be that God is both the source of knowledge and he also possesses the knowledge.   >Ah but we have established that God can very well flood everyone through his own power, so why must he work through the evil of men?  Because both are completely different scenarios. In the case of the flood, God only allowed Noah and His family to live. As it was stated, the rest of the entire world was too corrupted. In the case of using the Isrealites to exact divine judgement via war on specific nations, not the entire world. a flood would kill the Isrealites as well as those not deserving of violent death  Another reason is to demonstrate that God always keeps His promises. He promised to never flood the Earth again. Genesis 9:11.

Some basic requirements are [listed in their website](https://www.scdf.gov.sg/home/join-us/uniformed-positions) in case you need to have a bookmark.  To answer your questions:  1. You will need to remove it as a measure of confidence. Most paramedics wear [short sleeved vests](https://nyp.jobscentral.com.sg/magazine/polytechnic-2017/img/scdf-masthead.jpg) so your tattoo will be visible.  2. Shift cycles go by this: 2 13-hour daytime shifts, 1 day of "reserved duty" (administrative work), 1 day off, 2 11-hour night shifts, another day of "reserved duty", and 1 day off. By mandate, any work that requires a total of 24 hours of employed work needs to be offset by 48 hours of rest, but because paramedics in SCDF work in staggered 24-hour shifts, there's some flexibility involved.  3. Could you elaborate on what specifics you want to pursue? Urban search and rescue? Mass casualty response? Emergency psychology? These fields are available once you have informed your officer-in-charge of your desired expertise. Usually after you have stabilised for a period of tiem, you can approach your officer-in-charge to plan your career.  4. This will be long, and my memory was taken from my discussions with fellow paramedics that I talked to in my time as a medic, so your mileage may vary.  To start, you will be attached to SAF Medical School seconded under the SCDF organization to train you up on emergency field paramedicine. The total time will be three years, with each year you're being tested on practical and theory work. You will be attached at least six months to a fire station (not sure if by choice or by allocation of manpower resources) to pick up the training on handling real-life patients. You will be mostly performing more advanced duties like needle injection and infusion (IV), airway tubing, vacuum suctioning, ECG and pre-hospital ACLS routines, advanced spine management, extreme traumatic injuries, inter- and post-natal emergencies, and first aid that an NSF medic isn't expected to handle. You will also be learning on field management (e.g. radio reporting, situational awareness etc.) to complement your paramedicine duties. Afterwards, you will be tested, and you need to pass 80% of your assessments to advance to the next level of paramedicine. Only after the completion of 3 years of training will you be officially a paramedic.  Afterwards, you are attached to a fire station, still, not sure if by choice or by current allocation. You have two overall in charge: the commanding officer for the fire station, and the paramedic officer-in-charge of EMS. You will follow the regulations as set by the fire station CO, (as an overall leader in charge of the fire station representing SCDF at large), and you will follow the occupation regulations as set forth by the OIC (operational procedures, case paperwork, medical logistics etc.). Depending on your level of experience, you can be seconded as an assistant to the OIC, or you can be posted as a fast-response paramedic (usually it's performed by paramedics converted from fire and rescue units).  Most firefighters are OK with paramedics, but because the operational framework is different (one deals with fires and rescue operations, the other, fixing the human body so that it survives the hsopital trip) the only other time you get together is in drills and exercises, as well as station bonding activities and various inter-department and inter-division activities. If firefighters are physically shiong, you, as a paramedic, it's a mental shiong.  Rewards may/may not include: letter of commendation by members of the public, appearing in newspapers, service awards. Not so nice things include: public complaints, which may affect your performance bonus.  Last but not least, at the very least, you are serving for a noble cause. May you live long and prosper, and may the odds be ever in your favour. Good luck.
